question_stem: Given that \(f(x) = 2x^2 - 12x + 23\) can be written in the form \(f(x) = p(x+q)^2 + r\), where \(p\), \(q\), and \(r\) are constants,

parts.question_text: Find the values of the constants \(p\), \(q\), and \(r\).
parts.solution_text:
To rewrite \(f(x) = 2x^2 - 12x + 23\) in the form \(p(x+q)^2 + r\), we complete the square.

First, factor out the coefficient of \(x^2\) from the first two terms:
\(f(x) = 2(x^2 - 6x) + 23\)

Next, complete the square inside the parentheses:
\(f(x) = 2((x - 3)^2 - 9) + 23\)

Distribute the 2:
\(f(x) = 2(x - 3)^2 - 18 + 23\)

Simplify:
\(f(x) = 2(x - 3)^2 + 5\)

Comparing this to \(p(x+q)^2 + r\), we have \(p = 2\), \(q = -3\), and \(r = 5\).
